sections.title: What Is an Emergency Fund?
sections.content: An emergency fund is money set aside specifically for unexpected expenses or financial emergencies. It's not for vacations, shopping, or planned purchases - it's your financial cushion when life throws you a curveball.

sections.title: True Emergencies Include
sections.content: Job loss or income reduction, medical emergencies, major car repairs, emergency home repairs, and family emergencies requiring travel

points.title: Starter Fund: $1,000
points.description: Begin with a mini emergency fund to cover small unexpected expenses.

points.title: Basic Fund: 3 Months
points.description: Cover 3 months of essential expenses if you have stable employment.

points.title: Full Fund: 6+ Months
points.description: Aim for 6-9 months if you're self-employed or have variable income.

sections.title: Build Your Emergency Fund
steps: Calculate your target amount (3-6 months of expenses)
Open a separate high-yield savings account
Set up automatic transfers after each paycheck

sections.title: Where to Keep Your Emergency Fund
sections.content: Your emergency fund should be easily accessible, safe from market volatility, earning some interest, and separate from daily spending. Best options include high-yield savings accounts, money market accounts, or short-term CDs.

sections.title: Pro Tip
sections.content: Jump-start your emergency fund with: tax refunds, work bonuses, selling unused items, taking on a temporary side gig, or redirecting a completed loan payment.

sections.title: Peace of Mind
sections.content: An emergency fund isn't just about money - it's about reducing stress and giving you options when unexpected situations arise. It's the foundation of financial security.
